Hence, Fear, with all your horrid train!</br>Of monsters dire, and shadows vain,</br>That catch the ill-directed mind,</br>And fast in iron fetters bind.</br>Ill-form'd, unshapen Doubt, be gone;</br>Some region seek to me unknown.</br>There all thy sceptic art unfold,</br>To this nor that opinion hold;</br>Assume each odd, fantastic mood,</br>Like Proteus in the briny flood;</br>Now bent on that, for this now seem,</br>As equal matter turns the beam.</br>Away!  your empire I disdain!</br>Be gone with all your hated train!

Let but the Muse to me impart</br>Some knowledge of the tuneful art,</br>Fast I deliver to the wind</br>All that disturb the peaceful mind,</br>To waft afar to Zembla's coast,</br>Condemn'd to everlasting frost.</br>And even, Melpomene, thy song</br>I shun, no more thy notes prolong:</br>Self-eating Care, and Sorrow fell,</br>Oft in thy sweetest measures dwell.

Undaunted Resolution come;</br>Oh!  deign with me to make your home:</br>Come, with that bold unalter'd brow</br>Which you in greatest dangers show;</br>You, who unmov'd can view the storm,</br>With blackening clouds all heaven deform;</br>The mustering tempest swell the deep,</br>'Till waves the angry Welkin sweep;</br>Hear thunders rend the vaulted sky,</br>And see the vollied lightning fly:</br>You, undismay'd in evil hour,</br>Can scorn th' unfeeling tyrant's power,</br>Though lawless rage the sword shou'd wield,</br>And carnage fill th' ensanguin'd field:</br>Come, all your power to me impart,</br>And give the bold and dauntless heart.

Hail, Comus, ever blithe and gay,</br>Soul of the heart-rejoicing lay,</br>Dear God of Mirth and honest Joy,</br>Come!  every painful thought destroy.</br>My Jessy too must join your train;</br>Without her ev'ry sport were vain;</br>Vain ev'ry joy that Nature yields,</br>The tuneful grove, or flowery fields.</br>For her, ye nymphs, a garland bring,</br>Compos'd of all the pride of spring,</br>Deck'd with the art of all the Nine:</br>This round her modest brow entwine;</br>That brow to self-conceit unknown,</br>Affected prudery's gloomy frown.</br>Disdain ne'er knew that happy place:</br>Enthron'd in all her native grace,</br>Fair Freedom there has fix'd her seat,</br>And reigns inimitably sweet.</br>She comes: — Now strike the tuneful lyre</br>With notes which only joy inspire.</br>Sweet Nature's song alone can please,</br>That flows with unaffected ease;</br>The barren strains of lab'ring Art,</br>Can never touch the feeling heart.

While Music thus her voice shall raise</br>In sweetest notes to Jessy's praise,</br>Light-footed fly the dance along,</br>Responsive to the joyful song.</br>Thus let us pass the fleeting hour;</br>The present's only in our power.</br>Thus grateful seize the moments given,</br>The gift of ever-bounteous Heaven.</br>Since dark, amid the searchless gloom</br>Of future date, poor mortals doom</br>Lies undisclos'd to human ken,</br>And scorns the fruitless toil of men.</br>
